content.description: Starts about 15 feet from the right end of the wall.  Aim for the largest break in the second overhang, then climb the face past a sapling. Lots of holds, but they are small.
content.protection: Good pro up to the overhang, but very little above.  Very small nuts are better than nothing.  Suitable trees for top-rope anchors.  There's also a nice block with cracks for a gear anchor at top.

content.description: One of the best 5.8 pitches around CT. About 20 feet right of the "right wing" climb up and through a small roof. The opening moves are easier if you are taller, and protect with small gear. Follow the broken crack to the summit, it protects well after a spicy start.
content.protection: regular rack, even used the #4 camalot. the runout start can be avoided by climbing into it from the left under the roof.
content.location:
right end of the right wing wall 

  no anchors

content.description: In the middle of the wall.  You want to climb about 3 feet to the left of where the overhang ends in some small, overlapping right-facing corners.  Pass to the left of a dark vertical crack and continue on the face to the top.
content.protection: Very little.  R is generous.  Best toproped.
content.location: Walk off right.  Trees at top for anchors.

content.description:
Starts about 8 feet from the far right end.  Pull the second small overhang wherever you can find the hands.  Continue up the face to the top following a small vertical crack. 

  Traditionally this route is rated 5.6 but (due to rockfall under the roof) it's much closer to 5.10 now.
content.protection: Trees at top for TR anchors.

content.description: Start on the crack left of the start for right wing, continue up past the bulge rather than following the crack.
In the middle of the wall, to the right of Yucca Flats.  Climb a straight line where the overhang ends in some overlapping, right-facing corners.
content.protection: Best top-roped. Trees at top for anchors.

content.description: In my opinion, the best 5.5 in the state.  The gear is not straightforward however, so it might not be a great choice for a beginning leader.  If you have a newer second, and are not afraid to run it out on thin placements, this is a great lead.
content.protection: Small cams for near the top, balnuts are handy.  one 3" cam for the start under the wing.

content.description: An exciting low-angle meditation.  Some delicate moves early, than fun and freewheeling to the top
content.protection: The Falcon Guide gives this an 'R'.
content.location: A few feet to the right of Herbarium (large right-facing corner) is a crack in the face.  Lost World is a few feet to the right of that crack.

content.description: Large right-facing corner on the far left of the wall. There's a prominent crack about 3 feet in from the corner.  Ascend the crack, using the corner if you'd like.
content.protection: Small and medium.  (A big cam protects the first few moves). A bit runout at the top but easier by then.  Probably a stiff lead for a new 5.5 leader.
content.location: Large right-facing corner on the far left of the wall.

content.description: Starting a little to the left of Yucca Flats, diagonal up and left following juggy, positive holds to a ledge at the top of the right wing corner. Â Climb over the bulge and finish up the small right facing corner to the top.
content.protection: R - If you're crafty you can find some small (sketchy) wires and cams here and there, but otherwise prepare for some serious runouts if you decide to lead it.
content.location: Start is a few feet left of Yucca Flats.

content.description:
Wall to the left of the Cracked Wall/Entertainer Wall. 

  Right Wing Wall is the largest, most open wall at Pinnacle.  The rock is exposed to the sun in the afternoon which means it dries quickly but can be very warm in the summer.  Lots of great face climbing, but the pro isn't great on many routes.  Suitable trees for toprope anchors exist, but bring 100-150 feet of static rope or webbing to reach them.
